**The Masterclass** 🎖️ 

Module 5 - "Medium Term"  📏

***What we want***

Problem: 
> Buy & hold investing doesn’t optimise to limit losses or increase performance. Additionally, short term trading requires too much time input and the emotional burden of execution is quite high.

My philosophy: 
> To form a process where there is an optimal balance between time deployed vs. maximising results.

Strategy Goals: 
> Must reduce risk relative to buy-hold
> Must maintain exposure to large bull-market moves
> Must exploit opportunities for profit
> Must reduce reliance on any single indicator

***Strategy and Asset Selection***

> In the realm of swing trading, asset selection can be important, but generally its not as important as the strategy itself. 

> This is because everything in the market is highly correlated. If all assets move mostly in the same direction over shorter terms, then the majority of the research must be on the strategy.

> The strategy, therefore, becomes the main consideration, _and the asset simply becomes the vehicle for the strategy.

> The strategy is the ‘Alpha’.

> Some assets lend themselves better to algorithmic development, but that’s a discussion for later in the masterclass.

> For the most part, you’ll want to choose BTC or ETH and swing trade using them.

***Swing trade sophistication***

We will be broadly covering 3 strategies:

> 1. Manual aggregation - We select a bunch of different indicators, combine them together and to create a bullish or bearish condition.

> 2. Algorithmic design - We look to understand, select and combine automated strategies, to form a powerful portfolio.

> 3. Python coding - Essentially #2 but with all steps fully automated. Covered In principle only, due to complexity. This means most of the detail will be in #1 & #2.

Not everyone will have the desire to go all the way to the highest levels of sophistication.

Thats ok. You can still get great results from using #1, Manual aggregation.

***Strategy Behavior***

> While there will be opportunities to deploy both mean-reversion and trend-following analysis, the majority of the time we will be focusing on trend following because I believe it gives us the highest exposure to alpha.

> This is mainly because gaining exposure to the positive skewness of BTC’s returns is preferable, and cant be obtained by mean reversion.

•




***Time Horizon Expectations***

> In all of the methods covered we’ll be using approximately the same framework as the S.DCA method, but adapted to be more aggressive in its deployment.

> The following charts should give you an idea of what to expect in general.

•




***It starts by looking at general trends you'd like to capture.***

> This step is important and requires some self control, as obviously we'd want to capture everything, but you need to be reasonable.

> If you fail to have reasonable expectations for your strategy you will fail before you've even began.

•




***Think of how you'd define high conviction trends and low conviction trends***

> i.e. double lines vs single lines in this chart

•




***Think of locations where you'd like to scale in & out of positions.***

> These areas are important to think about conceptually, however identifying them in practice will be very difficult. Therefore the majority of the focus will be on trend classification.

•




***Familiarize yourself with the time horizons***
***And trade magnitude***

•




***You don't have to go long/short to make crazy money, you can just go long only.***

•




***Understand the power of compounding your positions just using cash when the overall trend is negative.***

> This is a hypothetical situation, however it does a good job of showing you what is possible when you get it right. 

> You go from 16x (buy and hold) to 58x (strategy) by getting your timing right.

•




***Understand the power of compounding your positions just using shorts when the overall trend is negative.***

> This is an even more unlikely scenario, but in this example we go from 16x to 85x.

> People think you can't get a 100x on BTC over the long run, as long as there is volatility we can extract performance from the assets.

•




***In case its not clear, this is the general idea.***

> In case you're thinking 'Why not just flip directions at the bottom'

> There's no way of knowing where that position is. Don't fight me on this, its not consistently possible. 

> If you keep trying to time all your exact exits in a mean reversion manner, eventually you will stop yourself out of a massive winning trade and you'll have no one else to blame but yourself.

> For this reason, the overbought and oversold levels in the medium term strategy will be a low priority afterthought instead of a core part of the strategy.

•




***Systemization vs. Discretionary ***

> It’s important to remind you that we are trying to eliminate the human element to increase our probability of success.

> The “active” part of the medium-term process is really the energetic manner in which you perform the research and development, not in the discretionary execution as you may mistakenly assume.

> Learn to hate discretionary trading and you will be on the fast-path to success.

***Summary***

> This part of the masterclass deals with the alpha driven dimension of medium-term investing.

> The strategy is generally more important than the asset selection, for this reason you’ll want to focus on BTC & ETH until you get far more sophisticated.

> We will be broadly covering 3 strategies: Manual aggregation, algorithmic development, and python coding

> Unlike long-term, we will be focusing on trend-following, not value identification (fundamental mean-reversion).

> The mental framework for our strategy will look like the SDCA strategy, but more aggressive.

> All strategy considerations will remove the human element where possible.

•




> **The Masterclass 36** 
>

***Time Horizons Introduction***

> People are always obsessed with indicators. But first we must understand TIME.

> Time is the thread which holds the fabric of the markets together. It is the common link between all assets and almost all analysis methods.

> Its common for people to mix time horizons (swing trading with scalping) in a attempt to increase performance when they find an indicator they like.

> Done naively, all this does is increase complexity and confusion with no increase in signal. 

***Issues***

> To prevent the risk of being drawn into an infinite labyrinth of confusion, the investor must DEFINE beforehand the REFERENCE TIME FRAME they will operate over.

> Failure to do this leads to people drowning in a sea of panic and confusion with every price move on every time frame, which is infinite in complexity.

> Price delines 3% - “Is now a good time to buy? RSI on the 30min chart is oversold”
> Price declines 15% - “Is now a good time to buy? RSI on the 4hour chart is oversold”
> Price declines 40% - “Is now a good time to buy? RSI on the 2day chart is oversold”

> All of these observations are subjective without an anchor defined by a strategy.

***Issues Cont.***

> Novices hit me up asking “Price is dipping on the 1 hour chart, I’m a long term holder, is this a good time to buy?”

> If you can’t see the issue here; you are the problem.

> This is the equivalent of pulling out your magnifying glass to inspect a paint chip on a supertanker about to sail across the pacific ocean, not only are there 100 higher considerations, it’s not a constructive use of an individual's mental capacity when starting out.

> Over-optimisation is not viable until you have achieved mastery at a single scale across all analysis methods. This may take quite some time.

***My Anchor / Guiding Star***

> Much like celestial navigation, one must have an anchor point, or ‘North Star’ on which to contextualise the behavior of the market.

> The trade offs for different ‘anchor points’ are apparent:

> Short time frames: More opportunities, more work.

> Longer time frames: Less opportunities, less work.

> I have previously chosen the daily (1D) chart as my ‘North Star’.

> (Now that I am more advanced, I do much of my swing analysis on all time frames between 1D and 1W)

> I never perform analysis on a chart lower than 1D unless I am performing discretionary trading, and even then I only use the 12H. 

> No method on earth can make money on time horizons shorter than 4/6 hours, and that's at a global hedge fund level. 

> Don't be naive and think you're special because you have a pretty indicator, because it wont work. Stick to a reasonable time frame

***Hierarchy of time frames***

> Some context which may be important is the relative importance of different timeframes on analysis.

> Generally, you’ll find that the largest drivers of market price are often also the slowest, at the highest level, this would be things that affect the desire of people everywhere in the world to hold risky assets.

> Economic growth, money supply, interest rates, inflation, etc.

> This means analysis done on higher time frames (longer term) takes precedence.

> Rule: High time frame (Years) > Low time frame (Minutes)

***Hierarchy of time frames (Advanced application)***

> The ideal time frame used in your asset class of choice usually is a step higher than the majority of the average market participants.

> E.g. If you’re trading a shitcoin which has just launched, you’re trading against retards, so you’ll probably gain an advantage by trading on the hourly chart rather than the minute chart.

> If you’re trading the broad crypto market, you’re trading against many other well informed individuals on the multi-hourly charts, so you’ll want to trade on the daily chart or higher.

> If you’re trading in the stock market, you’re trading against all the most well informed people on the planet, so trading over anything less than the weekly or monthly charts, targeting multi-month trade durations, will probably not work.

•




A practical example: When things look too chaotic…
…You’ll often find zooming out clears things up

***Risks***

> Obviously there is a trade-off between speed and accuracy, and really this makes perfect sense due to the EMH.

> This is the same reason why long term investing is in general more profitable for most people. 

> Not only do they:
> Have longer to make a decision, making emotional control easier...
> On average the signals are clearer, leading to higher accuracy

***Story Time***

> Levels of market fear or greed can change even when the price doesnt move, all we require is more TIME spent at a certain extreme price.

> Sometimes we can be in a very deep drawdown but people will still be hopeful for a quick recovery. 

> This short duration of suffering is not enough to completely clean out all the market participants who are still holding positions, their hope is still too high.

> To build the strength needed for the next bull market, you need a prolonged bear market to exchange the assets from weak holders to strong holders. No new bull market can start until this process is completed.

***Summary***

> Obsessively trying to find the one magic indicator which will solve all of your problems will only lead to annihilation.

> Clearly defining your time horizon and chart resolution will prevent you from becoming ‘lost’.

> The hierarchy of timeframes means analysis done on higher time frames (longer term) takes precedence.

> If you’re finding analysis on one particular time frame too difficult, zoom out to the next highest time frame.

•




> **The Masterclass 37** 
>

***Analysis Introduction***

> Unfortunately not all analysis principles used in long term investing translate well into swing trading.

> Where long term deals with valuation, a VERY high time frame form of MEAN-REVERSION, for swing trading I have found the most success with trend following.

> TREND FOLLOWING follows where the market goes next, it takes multiple small losses in ranging markets followed by BIG wins in trending markets.

> Trend following is ideal for taking advantage of the large sweeping bull and bear markets that crypto is characterized by. Aka 'capturing skew'.

> ***I need to make sure this is FUCKING crystal clear*** 👺 

> ***LONG TERM VALUATION = MEAN REVERSION STYLE OF ANALYSIS***

> ***MEDIUM TERM TREND FOLLOWING IS NOT TO BE ASSOCIATED WITH LONG TERM VALUATION***

***THE TWO DO NOT MIX***

> ***IF YOU MIX THE TWO, ITS LIKE TRYING TO BAKE A CHOCOLATE BIRTHDAY CAKE WITH TOMATOES, PARMESAN, ANCHOVIES AND HOT-SAUCE.***

> ***DON'T LET ME FIND YOU MAKING THIS MISTAKE***

***How much analysis must be done?***

> All methods of medium term market timing have flaws. There is no indicator that will guarantee you make money with a 100% hit rate, or even a 80% hit rate. 

> Many analytical methods by themselves are below 50% due to market competition.

> This means we must diligently perform analysis using multiple techniques to gain a holistic, probabilistic edge in the market above random chance.

> Obsessively trying to find the one magic indicator which will solve all of your problems will only lead to annihilation. 

> This is one of the problems systemization attempts to solve.

***What Analysis Types?***

> Looking at the hierarchy of analytical methods in the swing trading context, starting with - ***Systemization ***

> This is technically a 'method' and not an 'indicator'. We are covering this in more detail in the following lessons.

> These lessons will be on manual aggregation, tradingview strategies, and python as described in the introduction.

> In these lessons we’ll be collecting many different indicators and combining them together.

***Fundamental Economics***

> Supply and Demand happens over all time horizons, however the types of economic effects one can actually deploy over short time horizons is too advanced for this masterclass.

> If you find indicators or data that fits into this category during your research, feel free to note them down for later use.

***Macroeconomics - Limitations***

> Macroeconomic effects have huge impacts in the crypto market. 

> However, Macroeconomic seasons as previously covered in long-term investing are too broad and do not provide much ‘signal’ over shorter time horizons.

***Macroeconomics - Alternative approach***

> Swing trading using macro effects can be based upon the understanding that if the stock market; cryptos most comparable risky asset class, is bullish... then crypto will also most likely be bullish as well.

> How we determine if the stock market is bullish at a professional level is very difficult and could be its own lecture series. 

> Suffice to say it would also need to follow the hierarchy of analysis methods.

> I keep my process very simple by applying some systemized technical analysis to rank the bullishness of stocks.

> BTC’s directionally implied relationship to other asset classes on short term basis can also be determined through asset trend and correlation analysis.

***On-chain data 🔗 ***

> While there is some limited on chain data that operates over short time horizons, I have not seen many metrics which produce reliable trend signals.

> Most on-chain data signals are concerned with overbought and oversold levels.

> For this reason I do not incorporate on-chain data, but I am open to it should the right data arise.

***Statistical Significance***

> Unlike the other methods, we all know there is an near unlimited amount of technical analysis indicators in existence. 

> Where short time frames are too competitive, and long time frames don't provide enough samples, medium-term term provides an excellent mix of acceptable sample size (frequency) and duration of trade (resilience to competition).

> Therefore we can attempt systematic technical analysis in two forms:

> ***Manual systematic technical analysis: 🔧 *** Observing technical indicators to see if they fit the desired behavior for the strategy you wish to deploy. Then running them in a rule-based manner to minimise human discretion.

> ***Automated systematic technical analysis: 🔧 *** Using software to test indicators and produce statistical reports on their effectiveness. These statistical reports tell us if the indicator actually produces alpha. Then they can be deployed without human discretion.

***Sentiment ***

> In my experience I have not found any useful trend based sentiment indicators for the function of swing trading.

***Analysis Risks***

> At this point you’ve probably recognized the main problem, and that is that there’s a heavy reliance on systematic technical analysis over the other methods described.

> Statistical significance, which is the category systematic technical analysis belongs to, is not very far up the hierarchy and therefore a suboptimal choice.

> Personally I find it difficult to reconcile this as preferably I’d want indicators higher up the list, but I have been unable to find many which are useful over a swing time horizon.

> The redeeming factor in this situation is that the methodology of combining and running technical indicators can be done quite scientifically, and this is how I intend on staying as true as possible to the principles of systemization.

***Summary***

> We will be using trend following analysis for our swing trading
> I am not yet aware of any fundamental economic, on-chain or sentiment based data that applies to swing trading.

> I am aware of some macroeconomic and systemized technical analysis factors that apply to swing trading, so these will be the focus of our systems.

•




> **The Masterclass 38** 
>

***Agenda***

> Overall concept - systemization - we’ll combine a bunch of indicators

> What that looks like in a spreadsheet

> You can be as simple or as complex as you like (Remember, diversification)

> Basic indicator scoring in a trend environment: Eyeball long/short/neutral

> Show example of how to score indicator.

> Weightings of each indicator? Weight ‘favorite’ things more heavily, vs. Equal weight to reduce estimation error.

> Advanced and objectively correct: Can do full regression vs expected future returns, then internally score on strength of signal.

***Manual Aggregation Introduction***

> The overall idea of this lecture will be to show you some basic concepts of how to think about designing your first legitimate swing trading system.

> In principle, it will be about systemization, and in practice it will be about how to organize the data you have so you can act upon it confidently.

> Just to refresh your memory, remember systemization is about having many edges running at the same time.

•




***This is simple***

> You can be as simple or as complex as you like.

•




***This is complex***

> EXAMPLE ONLY - Do not just blindly fucking copy this. Think about what you're doing for fuck sakes.

***How to actually aggregate each piece of information***

> As we’ve learned from the statistics section, having a universal measurement for the scoring is important.

> However because we want to cover a range of effectiveness and complexity, I will cover two ways of doing this. Basic and advanced.

> Basic will provide an interpretive score, but no indication of strength.

> Advanced will provide a calculated score with strength.

***Basic trend scoring***

> When performing basic trend scoring, things are either indicating prices will rise, prices will fall, or neutral when there is not enough information to make a determination.

To represent this we will use:
> 1 = Trend Up
> -1 = Trend Down
> 0 = No Trend/Neutral/Undetermined

•




***Basic scoring indicators*** - They can be raw indicators

> Example: The green is +1, and the red is -1.
> 
> Pretty fucking simple eh?

•




> Same principle, slightly different indicator

•




***Be careful of indicators that whip you backwards and forwards a lot.***

> Generally there is an inverse correlation between accuracy and speed.

•




> Indicators cannot be discrete, binary or serve any other function other than identifying trend - This indicator will not work because it does not contain any information on trends.

> If you can't see that this indicator is not useful, then you should be concerned with your ability to accurately classify useful indicators
Same problem. This is not a trend indicator.

•




> This one is a tricky one because technically it can do both mean reversion (extreme values high/low) and trend following (above/below mid-line).

•




***When you have a couple indicators you like, you can put them together like this:***

> As you can see this is a simple average of all the components.
> You can choose to weigh the indicators differently, for example, give more importance to Trend Indicator 1.

> You can do this by arbitrarily including it twice, or perhaps changing the average formula to a weighted average formula.

> For the sake of error minimization and simplicity, my research has shown that even in advanced matters of analysis, a basic average is sufficient.

***Advanced & objectively correct***

> The more advanced and objectively correct manner of doing trend analysis would be to gather statistics on the future implied returns of each indicator, and then combine all the predictions to see if the average predicted return is bullish or bearish.

> Of course this wouldn’t be the end, the implied return would need to be compared to the historical returns and tested for significance.

> If the average predicted return is within 1 standard deviation of average historical returns, an argument could be made that the model is not actually producing any signal.

•




> For example, when the BTC F&G index is @ 12, the future returns are 10% over 20 days… Is this significant?

•




> It turns out the SD of all 20d samples since the F&G index was created is actually 18%.

> The F&G index has a lower implied return than what you could consider its ‘normal’ volatility. 

> Now IGNORING the fact the F&G index is meant to be a mean-reversion indicator, the implication is that the indicator contains no useful information, even though in the 'simplified' system we'd give it a score of +1 or -1 without thinking about it.

The reason why the simple method can be used in favor of the advanced method is that once multiple indicators are aggregated, in agreement, and behaving in the same manner, the significance of the TPI is extremely high.
﻿
***Summary***
﻿
The point I’m making here is that one method is easy and approximately correct, the other is extremely complex and could lead you down a rabbit hole of insanity.
﻿
The complex example hasn’t even been comprehensively explained and It’s many times more complex than what I have actually shown.
﻿
For this reason I think swing traders would do well to have a solid understanding of just the basic method using long/short/neutral; +1/-1/0 for the heavy lifting.

> **The Masterclass 39** 
>

***Agenda - Introduction***

We’re going to cover a couple of hacks to get the best out of your system:

> weighting of classes of components
> time coherence - constructive and destructive 
> trend score behavior

•




***Weights.***

> You can see in this system there has been some attempt to diversify between inputs, this ***decreases*** the probability that a minor calculation or estimation error from any input will have a major negative impact on the system. 

> You don't want your system to be overly reliant (weighted) on any one factor or input. This can happen when the system is still new and very small.

> Obviously if you only have 2 indicators, you're overly weighted to each indicator. This is not enough diversification.

> "How many is enough" I can hear your stupid ass asking.

> No amount is enough, but the QUALITY MUST REMAIN HIGH

•




***Weights.***

Assuming all the inputs are of good quality we have a couple of different things going on in here.

> Diversification of indicators
> Diversification of THEMES

An example of diversification of indicators is where I have written 'trend occilator #1' and 'trend occilator #2'. Basic shit.

An example of diversification of themes is:
> We have like 1/3 inputs coming directly from raw indicators
> We have like 1/3 coming from algorithms/strategies
> We have like 1/3 coming from implied macro correlations
> We also have some random other things scattered in there

***Do not become over-reliant on one indicator for your TPI, even if it is AMAZING.***

> They all have faults, giga over-weighting one thing will expose you to the same problems as that indicator. And that's the exact thing were trying to avoid.

***Problems with weights and diversification***

> I see it constantly, people read all this and go 'great, I have to fill my TPI up with a heap of SHIT so that its nice and diversified'

> Wrong.

> You'd be better off using ONE indicator than stuffing your TPI with a whole bunch of random shit if its all not working in synergy...

> Which leads directly into the next point

•




***What is time-coherence?***

> Time-coherence is the practice of selecting indicators/inputs which you have a reasonable belief to be operating over the same time horizons as your desired signal.

> You may be always using the 1D chart, but if one indicator or signal is very fast, and another is very slow, then your TPI will be vulnerable to unwanted interference.

> Constructive interference is where two waves reinforce each other.
> Destructive or mixed interference is where waves cancel each other out and cause problems.

> Failure to account for this will result in your TPI not working as intended. It may begin to fire too often, fire excessive false signals, or not fire at all when you need it to.

•




> Lets say hypothetically, you wanted to ‘classify’ this entire move down with two indicators, but you wanted them to retain time-coherence.

•




> If you’re using HA candles and a moving average, then they will require different time frames. 

> The 1D chart recommendation in previous lectures is not a straight jacket, and in this context, arbitrarily adhering to it would violate the interference principle because clearly HA is operating at a higher frequency than the MA.

•




You can see on the 6D chart this is the time frame the moving average gets the bear market approximately correct

•




But you can see here it wasn’t until the 17D chart that all the correct Hiken Ashi bars turned red.

•




This is a good first step, but its good practice to go one step further, and look through history to determine if that indicator time horizon reflects your time-goals, & how fast it reacts etc.

***TREND SCORE BEHAVIOR***

> You’ve created your TPI and now understand the ‘weight of the evidence’ approach.

> Now how does the signal behave? 

> Sure, above zero is long, below zero is short... BUT are there additional nuances we can explore?

> Yes, understanding the next point on TPI behavior will unlock another 100% more effectiveness. It will be like unlocking another badass indicator for free.

> Time to go from novice to master.

•




***Basics.***

> Using this indicator as an example, you can see that like our TPI, when it crosses the center, it signals a change in direction.

•




> However there are also cases where a weakening of the trend signal actually precedes the change in direction.

Observing the ***change*** in trend strength can prepare you for an ***actual change*** in trend.
﻿
If you have reason to believe the price is either overbought or oversold, you’ll probably notice that your aggregate trend score will begin to weaken when coming back and forwards from extremes.
﻿
Likewise if you are in a trend and the trend strength keeps increasing in your favor, up or down, look for opportunities to increase conviction of your positions.

•




> This is not always the case as you can clearly see, which is why its best to use weakening trend strength as an expectation of a signal, rather than an immediately actionable signal in itself.

***Summary***

> Try your best to diversify between system inputs. Diversification between indicators, and diversification between themes.

> The more the better, as long as the quality is kept high.

> Don't get tunnel vision on one indicator

> The TPI component examples are NOT to be taken as some magical perfect mix of indicators and inputs you should model your TPI on. Its just and example.

> time coherence - make sure input signals are operating over the same intended time horizon

> trend score behavior - above/below zero is good. Understanding the changing behavior is better.

•




> **The Masterclass 40** 
>

***Introduction - Backtesting problems with TPI’s***

> If you wanted to double check that your TPI performs in the way you expect, you’d perform a backtest.

> Back-testing is a method of verifying that a system or indicator, historically performs in the way you expect it to. Without a backtest you can never be sure if it will actually behave the way you expect.

> There is a limitation to the speed and accuracy with which we can backtest TPI’s due to their disparate construction. Collecting and backtesting TPI’s is laborious task, and can be improved upon.

***Introduction - Problems with Biases in TPI’s***

> TPI’s also require subjective human judgement on the measurement of some indicators, or perhaps the combination of multiple data sources which are dependent on one-another.

> For example, if you have a trend indicator going above or below zero, but it’s more accurate if its delayed by exactly 1 day each time, or perhaps you get slightly higher performance on a different time frame.

> All this additional information that needs processing increases your brains sensitivity to biases.

***Solution - Automation***

> If we were to automate the process of data measurement and aggregation then we would not only remove a significant degree of bias, but we would also be able to backtest some inputs very quickly

> Thankfully we have a means of doing this that is only moderately complicated.

> TradingView ‘Strategies’

> TradingView ‘Strategies’ are systematic technical analysis algorithms that help you automate parts of the signal generation process.

•




***How do you find them?***

Basic Pre-built strategies are avaliable in TV. They are completely useless, but good for functional examples.

•




***How do you find them?***

Community Scripts in TV are 99% conceptual trash and probably 1% conceptual gold.

Community scripts are good for inspiration and collecting ideas, but it’s unlikely anyone will be giving away an working strategy for free. Don’t be naive.

And if you find one, its probably not 'robust'. More on 'robustness' later in the masterclass.

•




A better way finding them is through the TV website. The TV website gives more information on each strategy and lets you filter by type/style of algorithm.

•




Again, you will find millions of strategies and 99% of them are unlikely to fit your criteria. Stay focused on what fits the mission.

If all this sounds hopeless and overwhelming, its because it is.

The majority of the time you'll probably find it easier and more effective to simply code your own strategies/algos using the knowledge you acquire the hard way.

This way you will have a comprehensive understanding of how they behave.

Coding is a subject for discussion later, and post-graduation.

•




***What do they look like? ***

Good screenshot presentation etiquette for sharing with other people and asking for feedback:

> Fully zoomed out price chart
> Fair distribution of space between top chart and bottom equity curve to see all the data.
> Even distribution of trades.
> Equity curve up and to the right, above buy & hold, or with high sharpe ratio.
> Low maxDD

•




***How do strategies behave?***

> It behaves exactly like you tell it to. Remember, these are not AI. 

> These are just instructions defined in code, which are automated.

***How do you use them? ***

> #1 - You use these strategies as directional signals in a TPI style system as shown in the previous lecture, or…

> #2 - You design one or more high-quality, sophisticated, stand-alone strategies, and have them make all the portfolio decisions. No TPI.

> Option #2 is preferred in theory because all the analysis being unbiased along with all the backtest data being readily accessible, your system will be superior.

***Which strategy to select? Which indicators work best?***

In the EMH lecture you were told that - “The things which do work are often hard, novel, require a lot of time and patience, suppression of critical cognitive biases, or don’t make sense.” 

> In this respect it should be obvious that this masterclass will not contain any specific recommendations for strategies, as the best methods, indicators and tactics are always changing.

> I provided specific advice in the first version of the masterclass and it lead to confusion as I made many dozens of changes and modifications to my strategies over the months.

> Therefore, discussion on strategy/indicator selection will be explored after the masterclass graduation exam.

***Summary ***

> Algorithmic TV strategies are an upgrade to the manual aggregation method because they reduce biases, provide data for backtesting, and save time via automation.

> You can find an unlimited amount of strategies on TV, however its unlikely of them will work, and of the ones that do, they will most likely have underlying faults.

> When you create your own strategies, you can either run them as signal inputs into your TPI for added complexity, or run them as a completely separate portfolio.

•




> **The Masterclass 41** 
>

•




***The scenario***

> Lets say you’ve done all your research and you have two amazing strategies that look like this: Nice distribution of trades, high performance, low maximum drawdown...

> The next question is how do you combine them? How do you know how much money to give them?

***Different types of strategies***

> You could do an equal split between strategies. But of course that would not be consistent with the portfolio construction methods we’ve looked at previously and would not maximise performance.

> If you have a strategy that is very safe, and a strategy that’s very risky, would you weigh them equally? Of course not.

> Thankfully we’ve already explored a model that can help us with this! MPT

•




Look at this image carefully. It conceptually applies MPT to strategy management.

•




And of course, just like MPT, your ultimate goal is to apply the omega ratio to the strategies.

•




To skip all the math and streamline this process you must upload your strategy equity to Portfolio Visualizer
(aka. PV).

Algorithmic strategies can be used to generate untold wealth by helping you find edges and separating you from the decision process.

But if you let unfavorable behaviors enter your strategies without oversight it can mean game over for your portfolio.

Now you know all the useful metrics, students often ask “Which is the most important one”. 

This question comes from a belief there is some universal hierarchy as to what makes a strategy good.

There is no ‘most important metric’, they are all important.

With this being said, the magnitude of the underperformance of a metric can cause them to become more important.

For example, if max-DD is 90% and net-profit is only 500% over 6 years, it doesn't matter if I create an arbitrary rule that ‘net-profit’ is most important, because no one would accept a 90% DD.

Likewise if max-DD is 50% and net-profit is only 1,000% over 6 years, neither one is particularly bad, but all things being considered, the strategy is massively underperforming versus buy-and-hold. Therefore net-profit becomes the most important.

***Summary ***

> Having a deep understanding of the metrics used to measure strategy performance will help you get the most performance with the least risk.

> There is no single ‘most important’ metric, neither is there a hierarchy of importance. The magnitude of a metrics underperformance will determine how critical it is.

> Your #1 concern is to negative filter, i.e. look for red flags. Think: Scientific/Statistical method, you're trying to DISPROVE the hypothesis that its a safe and profitable strategy. If you're unable to fault it within reason, its a good strategy.

> Sometimes the majority of a strategies positive or negative performance can come from just one side of the strategy (long/short). Consider eliminating the underperforming side of the strategy if this is the case.

***Terminology clarification:***

> To make it explicit, 'Forward-testing' is called such because we are effectively creating a 'sample' of our performance forwards through time.

> There's no way of knowing the population of our strategy returns, because time is never finished.

> Therefore you're always 'testing' your strategy even when you consider it 'finished enough for deployment' and are actively running it.

> **The Masterclass 44** 
>

***Counterpoint:***

> Automation can be extremely beneficial in the short term, and very hazardous in the long run. Subconsciously, automation makes you think there's such a thing as a 'finished' system.

> Once you code it all up and its working, then you get to enjoy the fruits of your labor and relax right? That's why we did it in the first place!

> Wrong

> I think the task of updating a system manually, forces you to comprehend if its actually doing what you want it to do.

> Its very easy to not look at, and engage with the internals of your system once its complete.

> Its like keeping icecream in your fridge and relying on your willpower to not eat it.

> If you automate everything in your system you're relying on your willpower to go back and keep it updated.

> Because I have all my systems semi-automated (i.e. the logic is fixed in a spreadsheet but the values are updated manually) I am always looking at how the system is working and thinking about its quality.

> If you're running an automated system, you may miss out on this extra 'brain time' that would have been allocated to your systems over the long run.

> Carefully consider if you have the discipline and habit to constantly re-visit the system before fully committing to automation, you might be inadvertently sealing your own fate.
